description.narrative: To enable the country with her rich biodiversity and biological resources to generate economic and social benefits for the country, benfitting stakeholders including indigenous and local communities.
capital of a political entity
An operational national regulatory and institutional framework on ABS

Financial and funding mechanisms established at federal and state levels to receive and reinvest proceeds from ABS agreements towards the conservation of biological diversity and sustainable use of its components

comment.narrative: No formal governmental financial mechanism exists for reinvesting proceeds from ABS agreements towards the conservation of biological diversity and sustainable use of its components

Financial and funding mechanisms established at federal and state levels by end of Year 3 to receive and reinvest proceeds from ABS agreements towards the conservation of biological diversity and sustainable use of its components

The TOR for the study on establishment of financial and funding mechanism to manage ABS proceeds monetary benefits has been developed reviews and endorsed in the National Steering Committee NSC meeting that met in May 2015 The study corresponds to the draft ABS law which include a provision that all monetary benefits where the Federal or state government is not the resource provider may require some percentage of monetary benefits to be deposited into fund that maybe established by the federal or state government to support conservation related activities

description.narrative: Institutional framework for sui generis systems for protection of traditional knowledge and customary uses of biological resources developed under the auspices of SaBC and used to inform national framework development

comment.narrative: No institutional framework for sui generis systems for protection of traditional knowledge and customary uses of biological resources exist for Malaysia

Supportive institutional framework for sui generis systems for protecting traditional knowledge innovations and practices and customary uses of biological resources developed forSabah State and used to inform national framework development

Sabah Biodiversity Council had given the approval for Sabah Biodiversity Centre SaBC to implement output 14 of the project on 26 February 2015 The Secretary of Natural Resources Office NRO has been appointed to chair the technical committee to monitor the implementation of the project
The actual work for output 14 by SaBC has not commenced The earlier proposed project by SaBC which is the development of a PIC communitty Protocol in Long Pasia Sabah needs to be revisited and a discussion on this matter is planned in the second half of 2015 This is to ensure that the project contribute to the overall ABS national as well as the states ABS processes

description.narrative: National and State Competent Authorities identified and operational for full implementation of national law and regulations on ABS

comment.narrative:
No national competent authority state competent authorities only exist for Sabah and Sarawak1
1 Sabah Biodiversity Centre and Sarawak Biodiversity Centre and Sarawak Forestry Corporation
National and State Competent Authorities identified for all 13 States and operational for full implementation of national law and regulations on ABS by end of project

Potential Competent Authorities CAs from all 13 states in Malaysia as well as some relevant federal ministries and agencies have been identified and are listed as Schedule 1 in the draft ABS law The CAs identified are the Ministry of Federal Territories state economic planning unit for the state of Kedah Kelantan Melaka Johor Pahang Penang Perak Perlis Selangor Terengganu Sabah Biodiversity Council and the Ministry Of Resource Planning And Environment Sarawak CAs will be responsible to oversee ABS matters in state especially in issuing access permit In the process of obtaining and finalising the list of Competent Authorities from states and other ministryagencies briefings conducted on 5 March 2014 and 29 January 2015 have increased the understanding of ABS issues among states the relevant ministries and agencies
in all states has been identified and currently some form of awareness is being done especially to ensure the nominated CA knows their roles in implementing the regulations later

description.narrative: Best practice ABS processes three are demonstrated recognizing the principles of biodiversity conservation Prior Informed Consent PIC and Mutually Agreed Terms MAT including the fair and equitable sharing of benefits
At least 80 of the population of ILCs participating in the pilot projects are aware of the existence use and option values of the biological resources under their stewardship

description.narrative: Number of best practice pilot ABS agreements and PIC processes disseminated at regional level

comment.narrative: Malaysia participates in UNEPGEF ASEAN ABS project but has limited experience to contribute to date
Best practice pilot ABS agreements and PIC processes presented at international workshop for ASEAN countries in Year 4 published in workshop proceedings and made available through NRE website
This output on sharing of best practices is envisaged to be implemented in the final year of the project where substantive project results and pilot agreements will be already in place

description.narrative: Number of ABS agreements arising from the pilot projects that specify conservation measures to ensure the security of the concerned biological resources

description.narrative: Number of ABS pilot agreements negotiated for initial commercialization of prototypes with fair and equitable benefit sharing provisions

comment.narrative: No ABS agreements in Malaysia that fully comply with CBD requirements
At least 2 ABS pilot agreements negotiated for initial commercialization of prototypes with fair and equitable benefit sharing provisions

The Forest Research Institute Malaysia FRIM and Sarawak Biodiversity Centre SBC are involved in implementing the pilot activities under outcome 3 FRIMs activities has been focused on documenting traditional knowledge from the Kintaq and Kensiu subethnic in the state of Perak and Kedah As of May 2015 10 plant species that are picked based on their utilisation linked to traditional knowledge are now under lab examination for further screening to determine their biological compound with the objective of deriving a nutraceuticalhealthcare product to be commercialised
SBCs planned pilot agreement will be done on plant based product derived from the Litsea cubeba plant which produces fragrant oil that can be used in many personal care product SBC is working very closely with the Lun bawang and Bidayuh Commuinty at Kg Kiding SBC is communicating with University of Portland Oregon on conducting a feasibility study for Litsea based products to be marketed in the USA
At least 2 ABS pilot agreements negotiated for initial commercialization of prototypes with fair and equitable benefit sharing provisions

The Forest Research Institute Malaysia FRIM and Sarawak Biodiversity Centre SBC are involved in implementing the pilot activities under outcome 3 FRIMs activities has been focused on documenting traditional knowledge from the Kintaq and Kensiu subethnic in the state of Perak and Kedah As of May 2015 10 plant species that are picked based on their utilisation linked to traditional knowledge are now under lab examination for further screening to determine their biological compound with the objective of deriving a nutraceuticalhealthcare product to be commercialised
SBCs planned pilot agreement will be done on plant based product derived from the Litsea cubeba plant which produces fragrant oil that can be used in many personal care product SBC is working very closely with the Lun bawang and Bidayuh Commuinty at Kg Kiding SBC is communicating with University of Portland Oregon on conducting a feasibility study for Litsea based products to be marketed in the USA

description.narrative: Improved capacities of national and state competent authorities for ABS implementation as shown byan increase of at least 30 in thedraft ABS Capacity Development Scorecard

comment.narrative:
ABS Capacity Scorecard baselines
NRE 33
Sabah 35
Sarawak 31
Other states 0
Other agencies0

ABS Capacity Scorecard targets
NRE 75
Sabah 75
Sarawak 75
Other states 30
Other agencies 30

The next capacity scorecard assessment will be conducted before the midterm review of the project in 2016 Upon the adoption of the draft national ABS bill in Cabinet and passing by the Parliament NRE plans to conduct targeted capacity building to the identified CAs on how to deal with access application and monitoring compliance by user of biological resources The capacity building or training to CAs as the regulators will be done based on a module that includes incorporating guidelines on mutually agreed terms and benefit sharing The training for CAs is expected to be conducted by early 2016

description.narrative: To strengthen the conservation and sustainable use of biological and genetic resources in Malaysia through developing the national framework for the implementation of Access and Benefit Sharing under CBD
Financial and funding mechanisms for the management of ABS monetary benefits

comment.narrative: No mechanism exists
Financial and funding mechanisms established and operational for the reinvestment of proceeds from ABS agreements into conservation

The terms of reference on the establishment of financial and funding mechanism for the management of ABS proceedsmonetary benefits has been prepared reviewed and endorsed by the National Steering Committee meeting that met in May 2015 Such mechanism is needed to ensure monetary benefits are managed in a systematic way thereby implementing the overall objective for conservation

description.narrative: National ABS law regulations and institutional framework in place which will enable Malaysia to accede to the Nagoya Protocol

comment.narrative: No national law regulations or operational institutional framework state legislation on ABS only exists for Sabah and Sarawak
National law and implementing regulations on ABS come into force by end of project and are applied by national and state Competent Authorities

All stakeholders consultations were completed federal agencies state agencies research institutions NGOs Communities and private sectors The draft Act is ready for submission in Parliament However at the moment the Attorney Generals Office is finalising the incorporations of some final comments made by research institutions NRE with the technical assistance of the Centre of Excellence of Biodiversity Law CEBLAW main focus in 2015 is to finalize the draft ABS bill and facilitate the process for the bill to be adopted by the Parliament in 2015 Finetuning of the draft ABS regulation will be conducted parallel to the process of finalizing the ABS draft Bill in the second half of 2015
National law and implementing regulations on ABS come into force by end of project and are applied by national and state Competent Authorities

All stakeholders consultations were completed federal agencies state agencies research institutions NGOs Communities and private sectors The draft Act is ready for submission in Parliament However at the moment the Attorney Generals Office is finalising the incorporations of some final comments made by research institutions NRE with the technical assistance of the Centre of Excellence of Biodiversity Law CEBLAW main focus in 2015 is to finalize the draft ABS bill and facilitate the process for the bill to be adopted by the Parliament in 2015 Finetuning of the draft ABS regulation will be conducted parallel to the process of finalizing the ABS draft Bill in the second half of 2015

description.narrative:
1. National law, regulations or operational institutional framework on ABS which enable Malaysia to accede to the Nagoya Protocol. Institutional framework for sui generis systems for protection of traditional knowledge and customary uses of biological resources exist for Malaysia. A formal governmental financial mechanism for reinvesting proceeds from ABS agreements towards the conservation of biological diversity and sustainable use of its components.
2. Establishment of national competent authority. Improved capacities of national and state competent authorities for ABS implementation as shown by an increase of at least 30% in the ABS Capacity Development Scorecard. Number of NCA, state and related agencies trained on ABS and bioprospecting related subjects to facilitate implementation of the national ABS framework.
3. Number of ABS pilot agreements negotiated for initial commercialization of prototypes with fair and equitable benefit sharing provisions. Number of PIC processes with ILCs implemented in accordance with the planned PIC/community protocol. Number of best practice pilot ABS agreements and PIC processes disseminated at regional level. Number of ABS agreements arising from the pilot projects that specify conservation measures to ensure the security of the concerned biological resources.

comment.narrative:
1. No national law, regulations or operational institutional framework; state legislation on ABS only exists for Sabah and Sarawak. No institutional framework for sui generis systems for protection of traditional knowledge and customary uses of biological resources exist for Malaysia. No formal governmental financial mechanism exists for reinvesting proceeds from ABS agreements towards the conservation of biological diversity and sustainable use of its components.
2. No national competent authority; state competent authorities. ABS Capacity Scorecard baselines: NRE: 33%; Sabah: 35%; Sarawak: 31%; Other states: 0%; Other agencies: 0%. No staff have been trained.
3. No ABS agreements in Malaysia that fully comply with CBD requirements. Some developmental work in Sabah and Sarawak on PIC processes. Malaysia participates in UNEP-GEF ASEAN ABS project but has limited experience to contribute to date. No ABS agreements in Malaysia that fully comply with CBD requirements or include specified conservation measures for related biological resources.

1.1: National law and implementing regulations on ABS come into force by end of project and are applied by national and state Competent Authorities.
1.2: National and State Competent Authorities identified for all (13) States and operational for full implementation of national law and regulations on ABS by end of project.
1.3: Financial and funding mechanism(s) established and operational for the reinvestment of proceeds from ABS agreements into conservation of biological diversity and sustainable use of its components at federal and sub-national level by 31 December 2018.
1.4: Supportive institutional framework for sui generis systems for protecting traditional knowledge, innovations and practices and customary uses of biological resources developed for Sabah State and used to inform national framework development.
1.5: Community protocols constitute the basis for clarifying PIC and MAT requirements between users and providers of traditional knowledge and biological resources.
1.6: Ethical code of conduct or guidelines for research on traditional knowledge and genetic resources.
1.7: Consultation completed with all states and paper on accession to the Nagoya Protocol developed for Cabinet’s approval
2.1: ABS capacity scorecard targets by 31 December 2018: NRE 75%, Sabah75%, Sarawak 75%; and other agencies 30%. 2.2: 100 staff from competent authorities, patent office, researchers, industries, MOSTI and EPU trained on CBD and ABS by 31 December 2018.
3.1: At least 2 ABS agreements initiated for initial commercialization of prototypes with fair and equitable benefit sharing provisions by 31 December 2018.
3.2: At least 2 ABS agreements that include in in situ and/or ex situ conservation measures as appropriate by 31 December 2018.

1.1: The Access to Biological Resources and Benefit Sharing Act 2017 [ACT 795] was adopted by the Parliament on 15 August 2017 and then published in the Gazette on 17 October 2017. The Act is anticipated to come into operation by the end of December 2018 or in January 2018 subject to approval of the ABS regulations by AGC and after all implementation mechanisms are in place. The revised draft of ABS regulations along with AGC’s comments was received on 2nd November 2018. A session with AGC will be conducted to review all feedbacks and comments received before the draft regulations can be finalized. 1.2: : Institutional framework including national and state competent authorities and supporting measures established to enable implementation of the national ABS law at federal and state levels. 13 Competent Authorities (CA) representing all States in Malaysia have been identified: • Johor – Johor Economic Planning Unit (EPU) • Melaka – Melaka Economic Planning Unit (EPU) • Pahang – Pahang Economic Planning Unit (EPU) • Selangor – Selangor Economic Planning Unit (EPU) • Perak – Perak Economic Planning Unit (EPU) • Kedah – Kedah Economic Planning Unit (EPU) • Perlis – Perlis Economic Planning Unit (EPU) • Kelantan – Kelantan Economic Planning Unit (EPU) • Terengganu – Terengganu Economic Planning Unit (EPU) • Negeri Sembilan - Negeri Sembilan State Forestry Department • Sabah - Sabah Biodiversity Council • Sarawak – Sarawak Ministry of Urban Development and Natural Resources • Federal Territories (Kuala Lumpur, Labuan, Putrajaya) - Ministry of Federal Territories
The agencies appointed as official checkpoints are: • Intellectual Property Corporation of Malaysia (MyIPO) • Ministry of Science, Technology and Innovation (MOSTI) • Clinical Research Centre (CRC, MoH) • Ministry of Higher Education (MoHE) • National Pharmaceutical Regulatory Agency (NPRA), • Universiti Putra Malaysia (UPM) • Universiti Teknologi Malaysia (UTM) • Universiti Sains Malaysia (USM) • Universiti Malaya (UM) • Universiti Kebangsaan Malaysia (UKM).
1.3: The final report on financial and funding mechanism(s) for ABS proceeds was completed in October 2017 and approved by the National Steering committee on 12 March 2018. 1.4: Melangkap Community Protocol is completed. SaBC is responsible to publish the protocol. This protocol was written by the community themselves with guidance from facilitator (BC Initiative). The community protocol consists of 7 chapters which covers the documentation of history and traditional knowledges of the villages and the PIC and MAT procedures to access the resources and traditional knowledge of the community. Long Pasia/Mio Community Protocol (first edition) is completed. This protocol was written by the community themselves with guidance from facilitator (BC Initiative). 1.5: Both Melangkap community protocol and the Long Pasia/Mio community protocol consists of 7 chapters which covers the documentation of history and traditional knowledges of the villages and the PIC and MAT procedures to access the resources and traditional knowledge of the community.
1.6: These protocols along with previous study conducted by The Centre of Excellence for Biodiversity Law (CEBLAW) & Ministry of Natural Resources and Environment on community protocols for communities involves in Sarawak and Peninsular Malaysia (Perak and Pahang) will be used as a reference/lessons learnt in developing the standard community protocol template that highlighting the minimum standard and procedures, ethical code of conduct and ABS user's guide.
1.5: The Cabinet had approved the proposal for Malaysia to become a party to the Nagoya Protocol on 26 October 2018. Malaysia deposited its instrument of accession to the Nagoya Protocol to the UN Treaty Section on 5 November 2018 and the protocol will enter into force for Malaysia on 3 February 2019.
2.1: Capacity building workshops was conducted on 9-10 August 2018 (Competent Authorities and Enforcement Officers) and 12 October 2018 (researcher and research institutes) to raise their awareness and capacity pertaining to the implementation of Act 795. More than 100 personnel participated the workshops. The ABS Users’ Guide, guidelines on the National Competent Authority and Competent Authorities roles and responsibilities as well as ABS training modules have been prepared to ensure effective implementation of Act 795.
2.2: The second phase of the Knowledge, attitude, and practices (KAP) second phase study has been completed and the final report was submitted in November 2017. A total of 1149 respondents participated in the Phase 2 of the study from March to October 2017 (550 institutional stakeholders, and 599 Indigenous and Local Communities). Terminal Scorecard: KATS (NRE): 51.28%; Sabah/SaBC: 77.27%; Sarawak/SBC: 68.33%; FRIM: 42.86%
3.1: FRIM successfully developed an herbal medicine product prototype based on the TK of the Semai community of Perak named “Pengloy Semai” in 2017; and an herbal product prototype based on the TK of the Kensiu community of Kedah named “KaHerbs” in July 2018. FRIM is in the stage to finalize the benefit sharing agreement with the Semai Community in Perak, and the Kensiu Community in Kedah. 3.2: Besides the existing 5 villages, SBC has expanded the Litsara project to 2 more villages – Bukit Sadok and Bakelalan which involve more community group of Iban and Lun Bawang. SBC is finalising the ABS agreement with the 7 communities participated in the project. From series of capacity building conducted by SBC, communities involved have been empowered by sustainable harvesting method Good Wild Craft Practices (GWCP) to ensure the population of Litsea cubeba plant is maintained and prevent over-harvesting, propagation of the Litsea cubeba plants to ensure continuous contract farming; Distillation of the essential oil at respective villages in a sustainable manner; Total of 5 community sheds has been constructed and each shed is equipped with 4 sets of the hydro-distillation equipment.
Commission Terminal Evaluation process and complete by end of 2019.

Terminal Evaluation (TE) was commissioned between July till November 2019 with completion of the following documents: a) TE Final Report b) Audit trail c) Management Response
A photo-essay highlighting the essential components of the project to be developed and published in Exposure platform and promoted in various social media platforms.
a) Financial closure by May 2020 b) Photo essay published in Exposure by May 2020 in conjunction with Biodiversity Day.
